summaries.body: A military plane crashed in a residential neighborhood in the Indonesian city of Medan, a military spokesman said.
Three American churches this week are considering resolutions to divest from companies deemed supportive of Israeli occupation in the Palestinian territories.
Staff members were evacuated from a prison near Melbourne, Australia, where news footage showed inmates with their faces covered, carrying sticks and beating doors.

posts.footer: Agence France-Presse's deputy bureau chief in Tokyo, on reports of a fire on the bullet train from the Japanese capital to Osaka, via Twitter

summaries.body: "We have been informed that a passenger in a car on the train covered him or herself with oil and set it on fire," JR spox tells @AFP
The body of a 17-year-old who died last week in Liberia tested positive for Ebola, an official said, seven weeks after the country was declared free of the virus.

display_asset.caption: Khader Adnan during a protest in the West Bank village of Araba in 2012. Mr. Adnan ended a 55-day fast on Monday after Israeli officials, concerned he could die, agreed to release him.

summaries.body: Israel's decision to release Khader Adnan, a prisoner who had been fasting since May, underscored the power of hunger strikes among imprisoned Palestinians.
South Korea said it had gone three days without a new MERS case, though an 81-year-old woman became the 33rd person to die from the outbreak.
The United Nations is reducing its humanitarian aid staff in parts of Asia, saying that Indonesia and other countries have improved their disaster-relief capacities.

display_asset.caption: Scholars say the Great Wall of China is disappearing as a result of erosion, theft of bricks and damage from tourists scrambling over unrestored sections.

summaries.body: Much of the Great Wall of China has been lost to erosion, tourist damage and villagers' stealing bricks, according to reports in the country's state-run news media.
The Colorado Supreme Court struck down a voucher program that allowed parents to use taxpayer dollars to send their children to private schools.

posts.footer: The Associated Press, via Hawaii News Now

summaries.body: Gov. David Ige of Hawaii said he would veto a bill banning sex trafficking and would ask for a new proposal. The state is the only one without a comprehensive law on the subject.
AC/DC songs will be added to streaming music services as early as Tuesday, sources said. The band has long been one of the biggest holdouts in the digital music market.
Research released Monday suggests Google sometimes alters search results to play up its own content despite people's preferences.
After criticism by advocates, immigration authorities will consider housing transgender detainees based on the gender they identify with, officials said.

display_asset.caption: Edith Macefield refused to sell her home to developers almost a decade ago. Now, the house could be torn down after the new buyers backed out on the sale because of the high cost of bringing it up to modern building code requirements.
display_asset.credit: Ian C. Bates for The New York Times

summaries.body: A house in Seattle that's popular with locals and tourists for its resemblance to the home in the Disney movie "Up" could be demolished after a recent sale fell through.
Dwyane Wade, the Miami Heat All-Star, will become a free agent after deciding not to pick up his option for next season. He was scheduled to make $16.1 million.
Discovery Communications won the exclusive rights to broadcast the Olympics from 2018 to 2024 for most of Europe, the media company announced.
The South Carolina Legislature appears to have enough votes to remove the Confederate flag from the Statehouse grounds, according to a newspaper survey.
Poisonings from a toxin carried by barracuda and other sport fish have been seriously underestimated in Florida, according to a study.
More than 26 million people overlaid a rainbow flag over their Facebook profile photos after Friday's Supreme Court decision on same-sex marriage, Facebook said.
Two fugitives appeared to have sprinkled pepper in their tracks to throw search dogs off their scent, as has been seen in movies. But did it work? Not likely, an expert said.
Bo Ryan, the men's basketball coach of the Wisconsin Badgers, said he would retire after next season. He has led the team to two straight Final Four appearances.
The California Legislature passed a bill that would require mandatory vaccinations for nearly all children in schools. The bill now goes to the governor.

display_asset.caption: Khader Adnan during a protest in the West Bank village of Araba in 2012. Mr. Adnan ended a 55-day fast on Monday after Israeli officials, concerned he could die, agreed to release him.

summaries.body: A Palestinian prisoner, above, who became a symbol of resistance to Israel’s occupation ended a 55-day fast after Israeli officials, concerned he could die, released him.
The L.A. County district attorney will unveil Monday a unit dedicated to reviewing the integrity of convictions for serious or violent crimes, joining a growing national trend.
France seemed to back away from getting the United Nations Security Council involved in the gnarled and stuck peace talks between Israel and Palestinians.

posts.footer: BBC via YouTube | The New York Times | The Guardian

asset.embed_html: <iframe class="embedly-embed" src="//cdn.embedly.com/widgets/media.html?src=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fembed%2F2XPO8B2QZ1g%3Ffeature%3Doembed%26start%3D214%26start%3D214&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Ft%3D214%26v%3D2XPO8B2QZ1g&image=https%3A%2F%2Fi.ytimg.com%2Fvi%2F2XPO8B2QZ1g%2Fhqdefault.jpg&key=170aca4a25074a88942b11f27e7ca43f&type=text%2Fhtml&schema=youtube" width="854" height="480" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

summaries.body: Glastonbury, the huge summer music festival, sang Happy Birthday on Sunday to the Dalai Lama, above with Patti Smith. The Guardian provided blanket coverage.
Rukmini Callimachi answered questions about her story of an American woman and a British man that may provide clues about how ISIS recruits new members.
California's legislature is expected to pass a bill on Monday moving to end exemptions from state immunization laws based on religious or other personal beliefs.
Protesters in Parwan in northern Afghanistan blocked the main highway there after U.S. forces raided the village of a local strongman and blew up his weapons depot.

display_asset.caption: A screenshot of a photo illustration used by the Democratic National Committee in a post on Medium.

summaries.body: Democrats are welcoming Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey to the presidential race with a post on Medium. But they may have more than one target.
Authorities in France took two managers for Uber into custody for questioning over suspected illicit activity involving its ride-hailing service, a spokeswoman said.
The director of a school in India was beaten to death by a mob after the staff was accused of killing two students, officials said. Autopsies later showed the boys had drowned.
Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain promised a “full spectrum” response to the assault that is feared to have killed at least 30 British tourists in Tunisia.
A woman severely burned in a weekend explosion at a water park in Taiwan died on Monday, the first fatality from the blast. More than 200 people are still in intensive care.
Graves in the Muslim section of a cemetery in Nottingham, England, were damaged in what is being investigated as a hate crime following the terrorist attack in Tunisia.

display_asset.caption: The student leader Joshua Wong at a Hong Kong hospital early Monday.

summaries.body: Joshua Wong, the 18-year-old student who led months of protests for a free election of Hong Kong’s leader, said he was assaulted by an unidentified man on a street.
A United Arab Emirates woman was sentenced to death in Abu Dhabi for murdering an American kindergarten teacher at a shopping mall in December.
Hundreds of people have been evacuated as a fast-moving wildfire in northern Washington State spread over 1,800 acres, threatening residential areas and dozens of buildings.
General Electric agreed to sell its fleet-financing businesses in the U.S., Mexico, Australia and New Zealand, the latest move to retreat from banking and refocus on industry.
Chadian security forces stormed an illegal arms cache east of the capital, killing six militants but losing five police officers, the government reported.
A strain of wheat that was genetically modified with an odor intended to repel insects called aphids failed in field trials, but researchers said they would work to improve it.

posts.footer: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, writing in The Telegraph, after an attack at a beach resort in Tunisia that is feared to have left at least 30 Britons dead

summaries.body: We must be more intolerant of intolerance — rejecting anyone whose views condone the Islamist extremist narrative and create the conditions for it to flourish.
Taliban militants kill at least 11 Afghan soldiers in ambush in western Herat province, Afghan officials say http://t.co/TF9LzKAnes
Australia on Monday was the first of 50 countries to sign articles to create the legal framework of the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank.
The Israeli Navy has intercepted a vessel with activists attempting to breach a naval blockade of Gaza and forced it to sail to an Israeli port, the military says.

posts.footer: Jeb Bush said during a trip to Nigeria in 1989 as a private business consultant on behalf of a Florida manufacturing company, via The Washington Post

summaries.body: My father is the president of the United States, duly elected by people that have an interest in improving ties everywhere.
After the Dalai Lama joined Patti Smith onstage at the Glastonbury music festival, the rock legend led the crowd in singing "Happy Birthday" to the Tibetan Buddhist leader.
A 75-year-old man from Oman who had become Thailand's first case of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome has been declared free of the virus, the Health Ministry announced.
Chris Squire, the influential rock bassist who was a founding member of the celebrated British band Yes, has died.
The aircraft Solar Impulse 2, which is attempting to circumnavigate the globe without fuel, left Japan for Hawaii after an unscheduled monthlong stop because of weather.
Some N.F.L. teams have used drones to film their practices, with coaches appreciating the new view. But the F.A.A. says the practice is illegal without a waiver.
The Edmonton Oilers selected Connor McDavid, regarded as one of the best hockey prospects in years, with the first pick in the N.H.L. draft.
Jimmy Fallon suffered a hand injury that required minor surgery, forcing the "Tonight Show" host to cancel Friday's taping. He tweeted a photo of his bandaged hand.

posts.footer: Matthew in Vancouver, Wash., in a comment on a Times article about the same-sex marriage decision. Read through a selection of reader responses.

summaries.body: As a relatively young gay man, I am glad I get to live in this time.
The University of Southern California's graduate school of art has only one student. Its dean explained why the program continues.

display_asset.caption: Dylann Roof was escorted from the Cleveland County Courthouse in Shelby, N.C., after being apprehended last week.

summaries.body: Dylann Roof, the suspect in the shooting inside the Emanuel A.M.E. Church in Charleston, S.C., was questioned by police in March. They found ammunition and parts for a rifle in his trunk.

display_asset.caption: Ava DuVernay
display_asset.credit: Amy Dickerson for The New York Times

summaries.body: Ava DuVernay, director of “Selma,” is running to be a governor of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the often-criticized group behind the Oscars.
Ryne Sandberg resigned as manager of the Philadelphia Phillies. At 26-48, the Phillies have the worst record in baseball.
Iraq confirmed that an Iraqi pilot was killed when his F-16 military plane crashed during a night training mission this week with the Air National Guard in Arizona.

display_asset.caption: Volunteers carried a man with heatstroke to a hospital in Karachi, Pakistan, on Friday.

summaries.body: The Pakistani Taliban warned they would take action against a power company if outages continued in Karachi, where a heat wave has killed at least 1,000 people recently.
Disney World announced a ban on the use of selfie sticks in its theme parks a day after a passenger pulled one out on a roller coaster in California.
After the MERS outbreak, South Korea passed a law authorizing jail time for people who defy quarantine orders or lie about their potential exposure to an infectious disease.
Sirius XM, the satellite radio service, will pay $210 million to major record labels to settle a lawsuit over royalties for oldies, the company said.
China is investigating a top sports official, Xiao Tian, for corruption just weeks before a decision will be made on whether Beijing will host the 2022 Winter Olympic Games.
A deadly explosion ripped through a Shiite mosque in a busy neighborhood of Kuwait's capital after Friday Prayer, causing several casualties, witnesses said.
Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve of France said he began legal action against managers of the ride-sharing service Uber. Taxi drivers protested the service on Thursday.
Militants from Shabab, an Islamist group affiliated with Al Qaeda, attacked an African Union base in Somalia, causing many casualties, the mission and an official said.
Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain has accepted that there may be no change to E.U. treaties before the country holds a referendum on membership in the bloc.
This is what passes for affordable housing in Silicon Valley: A freelance web developer recently posted an Airbnb listing for a tent in his backyard for $899 a month.
I'm also very excited to confirm today that a new play called Harry Potter and the #CursedChild will be opening in London next year.
#UPDATE Chinese shares close down more than 7% http://t.co/djYIFvvXwv
President François Hollande of France condemned the violent protests against Uber, but he added that the company's low-cost service should be dismantled.

posts.footer: Phil Robertson of Human Rights Watch, via Twitter

summaries.body: The Thai government prevented Human Rights Watch from holding a news conference in Bangkok on the persecution of religious minorities in Vietnam, the group said.
The famous V-J Day kiss in Times Square took place at 5:51 p.m., say astronomers who analyzed shadows in the photo. It's still unclear who the sailor and the nurse were.

display_asset.caption: The Dalai Lama in Rome in December.

summaries.body: Along with Kanye West and Pharrell Williams, the Glastonbury music festival in Britain this weekend will feature the Dalai Lama, who will discuss "the oneness of humanity."

posts.footer: A Times sports reporter on reaction to the N.B.A. draft, via Twitter

summaries.body: "It's darkness. It's winter. It's a trash heap. It's so sad." -optimistic Knicks fan on local sports talk radio just now
Responding to State Department criticism of its record on human rights, China said the United States suppressed minority voting rights and was "haunted" by gun violence.
South Korea imposed financial sanctions on a Taiwanese businessman and others accused of being involved in arms deals with North Korea.

display_asset.credit: Kadir van Lohuizen for The New York Times

summaries.body: The melting of Greenland's ice sheet is causing earthquakes, according to a new study.
Relatives of an Australian nun killed when Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crashed in Ukraine said her rosary beads and other items found at the site were stolen in a burglary.
European Union leaders have agreed to relocate 40,000 refugees over the next two years, but did not reach an agreement on a quota system.
The mother of Jason Rezaian, a Washington Post reporter incarcerated in Iran, said Thursday that he is finding prison life "ever more difficult."

display_asset.credit: Stan Lim/The Press-Enterprise, via Associated Press

summaries.body: An air attack on the 23,199-acre Lake fire in California resumed Thursday, a day after aircraft were grounded because of danger presented by two drone sightings.
Undated video posted online appears to show Russian-backed separatists in the Ukrainian city of Donetsk destroying a monumental sculpture in an art space.
Karenzi Karake, the chief of Rwanda's intelligence service who is wanted in Spain on war crimes charges, was granted bail by a court in Britain.
The N.F.L. Hall of Famer Warren Sapp will face charges from an April incident in which he's accused of biting his girlfriend, throwing her to the ground and stepping on her head.

display_asset.caption: Students scooting under the gates of the United States Embassy in Bujumbura, Burundi, on Thursday as the police sought to break up their encampment.

summaries.body: Scores of students crawled under the gates and scaled the walls of the U.S. Embassy in Burundi to escape local police as political tensions in the country escalate.
Haiti's prime minister said the Dominican Republic is creating a humanitarian crisis with its migrant crackdown. More than 14,000 people have crossed the border.
President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia spoke by phone for the first time since February, discussing Iran, Syria, Ukraine and the Islamic State.
Facebook must turn over any information it has that could help a woman find out who published a sex video of her without her consent, a Dutch court ruled.
Myanmar’s military blocked moves to rescind its veto power in Parliament and refused to ease a rule that helps prevent the opposition leader from becoming president.

display_asset.credit: Erika Schultz/The Seattle Times, via Associated Press

summaries.body: Clint Dempsey, the U.S. national team captain, was banned for two years from the U.S. Open Cup for tearing up a referee’s notebook during a match last week, shown above.
Dzohkhar Tsarnaev, who was sentenced to death on Wednesday for the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, has been moved America's toughest federal prison.

display_asset.caption: A Lululemon "Wear With All" jacket, one of the outfits with recalled drawstrings.

summaries.body: Lululemon is recalling 318,000 women's tops because of drawstrings that can snap back and cause eye and face injuries.
A district attorney in California said the collapse of a balcony that killed six Irish students will be investigated to determine whether criminal charges are warranted.
The State Department criticized Iran’s record on human rights a day before Secretary of State John Kerry's trip to try to conclude a nuclear accord with the country.
Google has started testing driverless cars on city streets in California, but the tests include a person in the car who can take control if needed, the company said on Thursday.
A nonprofit organization that claimed it could turn gay men straight through so-called conversion therapy violated New Jersey's Consumer Fraud Act, a jury found.
Bill Gates says he will contribute $2 billion of his own money to energy projects that reduce emissions and avoid using fossil fuels, doubling his current investment.
